Description: Black steatite shabti of Sunero: in this superbly carved funerary figurine the high-ranking military officer, the Master of Horse, Sunero himself is represented. He is not mummiform but is dressed fashionably, sporting a chin beard and wearing a wig with waved strands of hair over the head and ringlets on the shoulders. A two stranded bead necklace and a broad collar overlie his elaborately pleated long linen garment which is completed by a fringed and pleated apron. Most important, Sunero clasps his human-headed 'ba' bird to his chest, and it clings to him with its winged arms. Yet down the front of the apron is the beginning of Chapter 6 of the 'Book of the Dead', the spell to compel the shabti to work for Sunero in the other world. The text continues around the lower half of the figure's back.
Curator's comments: On the title of Master of Horses, see A. Ashmawy, 'The administration of Horse stables in ancient Egypt', Egypt and the Levant 24 (2014), 121-139

The 'ba' was one of the spirit forms believed to survive death. It was a complex entity but perhaps represents the characteristics or personality of the deceased, the individual traits which distinguish its owner from everyone else. Always represented as a human-headed bird, the 'ba' was the most widely ranging of all the spirits which survived death and was able to assume different forms to do so. The original concept that a shabti represented the deceased did not die out as soon as the idea became current that it represented a servant of the deceased who would act as its owner's substitute when agricultural labor was required in the afterlife. The two contradictory concepts existed side by side for a considerable period as this figure demonstrates. Bibliography: 'Egyptian Treasures' [exhibition catalogue] (Shanghai, 1999), 202-203 No 60.
